action.action-desc: Ms. Jacobs of California (for herself, Mr. Malinowski, Mr. Crow, and Mr. Castro of Texas) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Armed Services

form.official-title: To amend title 10, United States Code, to provide for the consideration of the human rights records of recipients of support of special operations to combat terrorism, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Upholding Human Rights Abroad Act.

section.header: Consideration of human rights records of recipients of support of special operations to combat terrorism
section.text: Section 127e of title 10, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (c)(2) by adding at the end of the following new subparagraph—

subparagraph.text: The processes through which the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall ensure that, prior to a decision to provide any support to foreign forces, irregular forces, groups, or individuals, full consideration is given to any credible information available to the Department of State relating to violations of human rights by such entities.
in subparagraph (H), by inserting , including the promotion of good governance and rule of law and the protection of civilians and human rights before the period at the end;

clause.text: by striking the period at the end and inserting or violations of the laws of armed conflict, including the Geneva Conventions of 1949, including—; and
by adding at the end the following new clauses:
vetting units receiving such support for violations of human rights;
providing human rights training to units receiving such support; and
providing for the investigation of allegations of gross violations of human rights and termination of such support in cases of credible information of such violations.

subparagraph.text: by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:
A description of the human rights record of the recipient, including for purposes of section 362 of this title, and any relevant attempts by such recipient to remedy such record.

paragraph.text: in subsection (i)(3) by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: An assessment of how support provided under this section advances United States national security priorities and aligns with other United States Government efforts to address underlying risk factors of terrorism and violent extremism, including repression, human rights abuses, and corruption.

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following new subsections:

Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3), no funds may be used to provide support to any foreign forces, irregular forces, groups, or individuals if the Secretary of Defense has credible information that the unit has committed a gross violation of human rights.

The Secretary of Defense, after consultation with the Secretary of State, may waive the prohibition under paragraph (1) if the Secretary determines that the waiver is required by extraordinary circumstances.
The prohibition under paragraph (1) shall not apply with respect to the foreign forces, irregular forces, groups, or individuals of a country if the Secretary of Defense determines that—

subparagraph.text: the government of such country has taken all necessary corrective steps; or
the support is necessary to assist in disaster relief operations or other humanitarian or national security emergencies.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed to constitute a specific statutory authorization for any of the following:

paragraph.text: The conduct of a covert action, as such term is defined in section 503(e) of the National Security Act of 1947 (50 U.S.C. 3093).

The introduction of United States armed forces, within the meaning of section 5(b) of the War Powers Resolution, into hostilities or into situations wherein hostilities are clearly indicated by the circumstances.

The provision of support to regular forces, irregular forces, groups, or individuals for the conduct of operations that United States Special Operations Forces are not otherwise legally authorized to conduct themselves.
The conduct or support of activities, directly or indirectly, that are inconsistent with the laws of armed conflict.

section.header: Consideration of human rights records of recipients of support of Special Operations for irregular warfare
section.text: Section 1202 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018 (Public Law 115–91; 131 Stat. 1639) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (c)(2), by adding at the end of the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: The processes through which the Secretary shall, in consultation with the Secretary of State, ensure that prior to a decision to provide support to individual members or units of foreign forces, irregular forces, or groups in a foreign country full consideration is given to any credible information available to the Department of State relating to gross violations of human rights by such individuals or units.
by redesignating subparagraph (G) as subparagraph (H); and
by inserting after subparagraph (F) the following new subparagraph (G):
A description of the human rights record of the recipient, including for purposes of section 362 of title 10, United States Code, and any relevant attempts by such recipient to remedy such record.

paragraph.text: in subsection (h)(3), by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: An assessment of how support provided under this section advances United States national security priorities and aligns with other United States Government interests in countries in which activities under the authority in this section are ongoing.

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsection (i) as subsection (j); and
by inserting after subsection (h) the following new subsection (i):

Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3), no funds may be used to provide support to any individual member or unit of a foreign force, irregular force, or group in a foreign country if the Secretary of Defense has credible information that such individual or unit has committed a gross violation of human rights.

The Secretary of Defense, after consultation with the Secretary of State, may waive the prohibition under paragraph (1) if the Secretary determines that the waiver is required by extraordinary circumstances.

The prohibition under paragraph (1) shall not apply with respect to individual members or units of such foreign forces, irregular forces, or groups if the Secretary of Defense, after consultation with the Secretary of State, determines that—

subparagraph.text: the government of such country has taken all necessary corrective steps; or
the support is necessary to assist in disaster relief operations or other humanitarian or national security emergencies.
